UK

UK PM May said that Britain has a broad agreement on the framework for a future relationship and that we cannot let the disagreement with Ireland leave us with a no-deal. PM also stated that she does not want to see the backstop having to be used at all and does not believe in the extension of article 50, while she added the UK is still aiming for a deal with friction-less trade at heart. (Newswires)

EU Diplomat said key issues remain open on Brexit and that the EU commission is not overly anxious on Brexit. Furthermore, there were earlier reports that EU Diplomats said a deal was not reached in the weekend because the UK wants a UK-wide customs deal and that they are ready to restart talks when things calm down in London. (Newswires)

Irish PM Varadkar said Brexit deal is still unlikely and that there are some things we can't compromise on, while he added that it may be December before a deal and that he is not clear how long talks will go on for. (Newswires)
 

EU

ECB Vice President de Guindos said Eurozone should continue to grow at an above-trend rate and noted that core inflation is moderate but should rise. Furthermore, he commented that risks include oil prices and the uncertainty from populism, while he added that Spain's economic recovery may have peaked. (Newswires)

Italy's PM Conte said Italy's cabinet approved 2019 budget and that the budget draft is to be sent to the Commission, while he added that the budget keeps the government's promises and keeps public accounts in order. Elsewhere, Italy's Economy Minister Tria said the budget measures are all fully covered and budget allows early retirement as well as basic income tools, while the League said there are no tax hikes in budget except on banks and insurers. (Newswires)

The Dutch government will lower corporation tax to 20.5% from 25%. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

Saudis are to say Khashoggi died from botched interrogation and to say intent was to abduct him from Turkey. (CNN)
 

US

US Retail Sales MM Sep 0.1% vs. Exp. 0.6% (Prev. 0.1%). (Newswires)

MARKET RECAP

Following the announcement of a merger of equals between defence names L3 Technologies (LLL) and Harris Corp (HRS), the two share prices jumped higher. Ralph Lauren (RL) was a top mover on the back of an upgrade at JPMorgan. Disney (DIS) moved higher following a price target rise at Morgan Stanley. American Airlines (AAL) and Altria Group (MO) were also other gainers on the day. Apple (AAPL) weighed down heavily on bourses today after Goldman Sachs said there were mounting signs that of rapidly slowing consumer demand in China, affecting iPhone sales. Activision Blizzard (ATVI) was a bottom mover, with some analysts attributing this to the co. not mentioning how its new video-game Call of Duty: Black Ops 4 did in physical sales, rather it just focused on digital sales. Bank of America (BAC) traded lower despite beating earnings estimates. Semiconductor co. NVIDIA (NVDA) was also down on the day, as was software developer Adobe (ADBE). SPX -0.59% at 2750.78, NDX -1.24% at 7068.67, DJI -0.35% at 25250.

Treasuries were lower on Monday though action remained in a tight range, with mixed retail sales only giving the complex a temporary boost. Less volatility also contributed to yields moving upwards; yields across the curve were higher by c.2bps across the curve at settlement. 10s30s and 5s30s were wider by c.1bps. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 6 ticks lower at 118-50.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 15th October 2018: Tech lags; VIX retreats to 20
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

 

  • * SNAP-SHOT: Equities mixed, Treasuries down, crude up, dollar down.
  • * REAR-VIEW: UK PM May urges temporary backstop, US retail sales mixed, Italy’s budget delayed to Tuesday, ECB's Vasiliauskas sees no reason why QE should not end, BoC Outlook Survey, Italy’s cabinet approves 2019 budget.
  • * AHEAD: RBA Minutes, Chinese CPI, UK Labour Market Data, US Manufacturing Output.

 

* BREXIT: After talks broke down late on Sunday, UK PM May addressed the Parliament announcing that Britain has a broad agreement on the framework for a future relationship with the EU. She stressed she cannot let the disagreement with Ireland leave the UK with a no-deal, adding that she does not want to see the backstop having to be used at all and she is working with the EU to ensure a backstop is time limited. She expects a UK-wide customs arrangement to end by December 2021, highlighting the government will not revoke Article 50. With regards to negotiations, the UK and EU called for a pause in discussions until Wednesday's summit; EU Diplomats stated that a deal was not reached on the weekend because the UK wants a UK-wide customs deal, and they are ready to restart talks when things calm down in London. Also, the EU was said to accept the UK backstop though clarifying it wants its own as well; it also wants its Irish backstop treaty to continue with its backstop as ultimate and fall-back guarantee. DUP's Wilson commented noting the EU's deal is worse than a no deal, and a no deal is inevitable thanks to the intransigence of the EU's negotiating position. Similarly, Irish PM Varadkar believes a Brexit deal still unlikely and he is not prepared to compromise on some things; he noted it may be December before a deal. In later comments, European Council President Tusk stated Brexit is more complicated than expected, urging the EU to prepare for no-deal scenario as such an outcome is more likely than it was before. He invited UK PM May to address remaining EU 27 member states on Wednesday night.

* ITALY: Italy's PM Conte said Italy's cabinet has approved the 2019 budget, with the draft se to be sent to the Commission. He stressed the budget keeps the government's promises and keeps the public accounts in order. Italy's Economy Minister Tria stated the budget measures are all fully covered, and the budget allows early retirement and basic income tools. He denied plans to resign after the budget is approved in Parliament; he stressed expansionary measures are necessary to counter the slowdown of the economy in the next year and says the deficit target is normalising. He also thinks the idea that the budget can spark a crisis in Europe is 'totally unfounded'. Finally, Italy's Deputy PM Di Maio noted the cuts are to 'privileges' to fund income for the poor and announced citizens income to start in Q1 of 2019.

* GEOPOLITICS: US President Trump said he has a different feeling towards Turkey now, with the coming after the release of Pastor Brunson, but he reported to have not made a deal on sanctions. CNN reported Saudis to say Khashoggi died from botched interrogation and to say intent was to abduct him from Turkey.

* RETAIL SALES rose 0.1% in September missing expectations at 0.6%, the control measure rose 0.5%, a tad above the 0.4% consensus whilst Ex-Autos fell 0.1%, missed the 0.4% expected. Overall the report was mixed with analysts at Wells Fargo noting that core spending remains strong though sales in bars and restaurants, which have been outperforming recently, posted a 1.8% decline. A 0.8% drop in gas stations’ sales also contributed to the headline miss. On the flip side, auto sales jumped 0.8%.

* ECB: ECB's Vasiliauskas said there is no reason as to why the ECB should not end asset purchases as planned. He noted discussion of rates could begin in the middle of next year, the rate decision could occur in Autumn 2019 if it is necessary. ECB Vice President de Guindos thinks the Eurozone will continue to grow at an above-trend rate; he noted growth risks have remained broadly balanced but global risks have become more prominent. Core inflation is moderate, but should rise. Risks include oil prices and the uncertainty from populism.

* SPX -0.59% at 2750.78, NDX -1.24% at 7068.67, DJI -0.35% at 25250. SECTORS: Energy -0.82%, Materials -0.48%, Industrials +0.22%, Cons Discretionary -0.47%, Cons Staples +0.60%, Healthcare -0.77%, Financials -0.51%, Tech -1.64%, Telecoms -0.43%, Utilities +0.35%.

* Stock Specifics: Following the announcement of a merger of equals between defence names L3 Technologies (LLL) and Harris Corp (HRS), the two share prices jumped higher. Ralph Lauren (RL) was a top mover on the back of an upgrade at JPMorgan. Disney (DIS) moved higher following a price target rise at Morgan Stanley. American Airlines (AAL) and Altria Group (MO) were also other gainers on the day. Apple (AAPL) weighed down heavily on bourses today after Goldman Sachs said there were mounting signs that of rapidly slowing consumer demand in China, affecting iPhone sales. Activision Blizzard (ATVI) was a bottom mover, with some analysts attributing this to the co. not mentioning how its new video-game Call of Duty: Black Ops 4 did in physical sales, rather it just focused on digital sales. Bank of America (BAC) traded lower despite beating earnings estimates. Semiconductor co. NVIDIA (NVDA) was also down on the day, as was software developer Adobe (ADBE).

* WTI (X8) SETTLES USD 0.44 HIGHER AT USD 71.78/BBL, BRENT (Z8) SETTLES USD 0.35 HIGHER AT USD 80.78/BBL. Crude has been trading mixed around the neutral line on Monday, with the market focused on the situation of missing (anti-Saudi) journalist Jamal Kashoggi, with some suggestions that Saudi Arabia has played a part in his demise. However, those concerns eased slightly after the Saudi energy minister assured markets that the Kingdom will remain a reliable energy supplier to global markets; additionally, US President Trump seems to have given legitimacy to the Saudi denials of involvement, hinting that the US may be less willing to impose sanctions on key individuals in Saudi Arabia (for now). Nevertheless, questions remain around whether Saudi Arabia could use oil as a politicised weapon in the event international action was taken out against it. UBS points out that not since the 1970s has Saudi Arabia explicitly used oil production as a political bargaining chip, and notes that it has maintained oil sales to Canada during the recent diplomatic spat; UBS believes the KSA cutting oil output in response is unlikely: "Saudi has no interest in causing a spike in the oil price that would once again incentivise the return of high cost producers who would threaten OPEC market share, and might ultimately threaten global oil demand," UBS wrote, "However, with Saudi production of ~10.5mb/d underperforming both the target set following the OPEC meeting in June (+800kb/d by end July, implying 10.8mb/d) and the (lower) figure reported recently both by Saudi's Oil Minister and in an interview with Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman (10.7mb/d), the current dispute may provide a convenient excuse for Saudi to step away from targets it was having trouble achieving anyway." UBS also adds that the dispute over the journalist's disappearance is unlikely to be settled soon and "it has introduced yet another variable that is more bullish than bearish for oil prices."

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLE 6 TICKS LOWER AT 118-50. Treasuries were lower on Monday though action remained in a tight range, with mixed retail sales only giving the complex a temporary boost. Less volatility also contributed to yields moving upwards; yields across the curve were higher by c.2bps across the curve at settlement. 10s30s and 5s30s were wider by c.1bps.

* USD: The Greenback has been on the backfoot since the start of Monday’s EU session, and retreated further ahead of early US data pretty much across the board. However, the DXY is striving to stay afloat of 95.000 from a low of 94.951 in wake of a conflicting retail sales report and uptick in Empire State manufacturing.

* CHF, NZD: Vying for top G10 spot and virtually neck-and-neck as the Franc bounces firmly from 0.9900+ levels vs the Usd and 1.1450+ vs the Eur to join the Kiwi on its approach towards 0.6550, the former shrugging off weaker Swiss producer and import price data and ongoing dovish SNB policy guidance, while the latter awaits NZ inflation data in the form of Q3 CPI that is forecast to be firmer than previous rates of 0.4% q/q and 1.5% y/y.

* AUD: The next best major and almost keeping pace with its antipodean peer, but capped ahead of 0.7150 vs the Usd, as the Aud/Nzd cross drifted down further from recent peaks towards 1.0900. Somewhat mixed impulses for the Aussie with ongoing US-China trade angst cushioned to an extent by a rise in metals prices.

* JPY, EUR: Also benefiting from general Usd weakness, but the Jpy also getting a safe-haven boost overnight amidst declines across Asia-Pacific bourses, while the latter overcame or withstood more Italian budget jitters to bounce off sub-1.1550 lows. However, decent option expiry interest also influenced both headline pairs as Usd/Jpy held above 1 bn between 111.40-55 and Eur/Usd under 1.2 bn from 1.1600-15.

* GBP, CAD: Relative underperformers with Cable floating around 1.3150 after an attempted recovery from sub-1.3100 lows stalled ahead of 1.3200, and Eur/Gbp re-testing 0.8800 on a breakdown in Brexit negotiations ahead of this week’s EU Summit. The key sticking point remains Ireland and the UK’s determination to avoid a hard border vs the EU reportedly willing to accept the back-stop only on the basis that it includes a separate and ultimate fall-back guarantee. The Loonie broke below 1.3000 vs. the Usd following the release of the BoC Outlook Survey, conducted prior to USMCA agreement, which noted that capacity pressures fell slightly but pressures remain elevated and broad-based.

* EM: Extended gains for the likes of the Lira, Rand, Rouble and Real, partly due to the aforementioned Dollar downturn, but also on the back of ongoing relief and retracement.

UBS weekly FX Flows: Antipodes & SEK most bought
content:
• AUD led G10 FX inflows on a normalized basis, registering buying interest every day last week amid higher iron ore prices and higher spot Aussie.
  • SEK was bid for a second week as buying interest from the prior week persisted amid a strong Sep inflation report.
  • NZD saw inflows despite broad risk aversion as New Zealand yields moved higher with global peers.
  • In line with currency strength, EUR buying resumed.
  • JPY was bought for the first time in two weeks with the strongest inflows at the beginning of the week, corresponding to the broad risk-off sentiment.
  • GBP was the most sold G10 currency on a normalized basis, recording outflows every day  last week as Brexit uncertainties linger.
  • CAD was sold for a third week as the discount for Canadian crudes widened to multi-year highs.
  • NOK was sold for a third week despite a strong CPI report while USD saw outflows amid the equity sell-off and another low CPI print.

content: Not much net movement in core debt in wake of a pretty inconclusive US retail sales report and slightly more upbeat than expected NY Fed manufacturing survey, with Gilts still outperforming Bunds on Brexit no deal risk, but just off new Liffe session highs of 120.82, +36 ticks on the day, as the latter hovers around 13 ticks above parity circa 158.66. Meanwhile, the Dollar is trying to regroup and reclaim some lost ground, but the DXY is struggling to regain 95.000+ status in any meaningful way ahead of the Wall Street open.

Elsewhere, the co. announced forecasts of 7,700 of new aircraft deliveries from 2019 to 2028. (Newswires)

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 15th October 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Cautious start to trade this week as Trump hints at further Chinese tariffs.
  • An unproductive Brexit weekend with negotiations paused until Wednesday’s summit, with some reports of no deal implementation plans beginning
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US retail sales and NY Fed manufacturing, Canadian Business Outlook, NZ CPI, Italian Budget Submission Deadline

ASIA

Asian equity markets resumed last week’s stock rout as the region failed to take impetus from Friday’s rebound on Wall St where tech outperformed and all majors finished a tumultuous session in the green, albeit with losses of around 4% on the week. ASX 200 (-1.0%) slumped from the open as financials and tech led the broad losses which dragged the index briefly below the 5800 level, while Nikkei 225 (-1.9%) suffered from continued flows into the JPY. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-1.5%) and Hang Seng (-1.4%) conformed to the negative tone with sentiment not helped by President Trump’s reiteration that the US may have to impose another round of tariffs on China, with indecision seen in the mainland after the PBoC skipped open market operations and refrained from rolling over maturing MLF loans as its previously announced 100bps RRR cut took effect. Finally, 10yr JGBs were pressured at the open and tracked the recent weakness in T-notes, but then recovered as the widespread risk averse tone spurred safe-haven demand.

PBoC skipped open market operations and refrained from rolling over maturing medium-term lending facility loans. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9154 (Prev. 6.9120)

EU/UK/US

UK and EU negotiators called for a pause in discussions until Wednesday's summit outcome. Source reports suggested that all negotiations between UK and EU are on hold with the UK government reportedly telling ministers to begin 'no deal' implementation plans after last-ditch discussions broke up. (Times/Newswires) The breakdown in talks came after UK PM May refused to endorse a draft Brexit deal negotiated by UK and EU officials on Sunday night amid concerns the Cabinet would refuse to support the plan. UK PM May labelled the draft Brexit agreement a 'non-starter' in its current form and advisers are reportedly trying to craft new language for the Brexit withdrawal agreement amid signs the Cabinet will otherwise refuse to agree to PM May’s backstop proposals. Furthermore, it was also reported that EU leaders may not call for a special summit next month amid lack of progress. (Telegraph/FT)

EU leaders are set to hold an extraordinary “no deal” Brexit summit with a date pencilled in for the weekend of 17-18 November, to deal with the potential disaster of the UK crashing out of the bloc should PM May fail to deliver decisive progress on the Irish border issue this week. (The Guardian)

Former UK Foreign Minister Johnson said UK is entering moment of crisis in Brexit discussions and that matters cannot continue how they currently are, while he added the UK must resist being pushed around by EU. (Telegraph)

Former Brexit Secretary Davis has called for a cabinet uprising against UK PM May as MPs and ministers said they are ready to oust her if she does not change course on her Brexit plan. Writing to the Sunday Times, he called UK PM May’s plan “flawed” and “unacceptable”, while he accused the PM’s aides of “incipient panic” in the face of Brussel’s demands and trying to cut out the cabinet from key decisions. (The Times/BBC/Sky News)

Multiple Labour MPs told The Independent that they are prepared to support the Brexit agreement UK PM May hopes to bring back from Brussels, while the newspaper was also told that at least 15 Labour MPs could rebel against Labour leader Corbyn and back the government, which could be enough to tip the balance in the Commons in favour of a deal. (The Independent)

Scotland’s first minister is to press the case for continued membership of the single market and customs union by unveiling a “common-sense” alternative Brexit plan on Monday. (The Guardian)

UK PM May has been told that DUP Leader Foster is “ready” to trigger a no-deal Brexit as she believes this is the most likely outcome following a “hostile and difficult” meeting with EU’s Chief Negotiator Barnier, a set of leaked government emails revealed. (The Guardian)

BBC journalist Tweets; " Sources say EU wants a Northern Ireland only backstop solution, should proposed UK wide backstop not be implemented" (BBC)

DUP's Wilson says the EU's deal is worse than a no deal, and a no deal is inevitable thanks to the intransigence of the EU's negotiating position. (Newswires)

Irish Foreign Minister Coveney; it is still possible to reach a Brexit deal but it is going to take more time than hoped. (Newswires)

EU Diplomats say that a deal was not reached on the weekend because the UK wants a UK-wide customs deal, and they are ready to restart talks when things calm down in London. (Newswires)

The EY Item Club predicts GDP growth of 1.3% this year and 1.5% in 2019, down from 1.4% and 1.6% respectively in its previous outlook three months ago. (BBC)

US President Trump reiterated the US might have to impose another round of tariffs on China. In other news, President Trump was reportedly unsure whether Defense Secretary Mattis will step down and suggested that Mattis was a sort of a Democrat. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said that no decision has been made yet regarding a meeting between US President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping at the G20 in Argentina, while Mnuchin also suggested the US would like to include currency stipulations in future trade agreements with everyone. (Newswires)

ECB President Draghi said underlying inflation is hovering around 1% but is confident it will proceed towards target, while he added that the main risk is a sharp repricing of assets or sudden increase in interest rates. Elsewhere, Draghi said he does not see room for additional expenditures in Italy and stated that ECB will not intervene to help Italy. (Newswires)

Germany’s CSU lost its absolute majority in the Bavarian state election and suffered its weakest result since 1950, according to an exit poll. (Twitter)

Sweden Moderate Party leader Kristersson is said to end current attempt to form a government after failing to receive enough support for a coalition. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

Main European Indices are mixed amid current market uncertainty; the Dax is up (+0.3%) despite being weighed on by Lufthansa which is down by over 3% following agreements on new employment conditions, featuring moderate salary increases.

Sectors are mixed with IT lagging at -1% as a follow on from poor IT performance in Asia due to continued U.S-China tension; this is despite Friday’s Wall Street rebound for IT which saw it as the leading sector finishing up by 3%.

Convatec are down by over 25% following a cut in their revenue guidance. Chr Hansen are up by over 2% following a positive earnings update and reports that their chairman will not seek re-election, with Dominique Reiniche to be nominated as the next chairman.

FX

JPY - The clear G10 outperformer and beneficiary of a downturn in Asia-Pacific stocks as jitters over global trade, protectionism and sanctions undermined sentiment. Usd/Jpy has retreated from 112.25 highs and through 112.00 to a 111.70 low, breaching the 55 DMA at 111.83, while Eur/Jpy is back below 129.50 alongside broadly softer Jpy crosses. From a technical perspective, 111.50 will be eyed next on the downside as a psychological marker and 50% Fib, roughly aligning with daily support around 111.47 plus decent option expiry interest between 111.55-40 (1 bn).

GBP - At the opposite end of the spectrum, the Pound has been undermined by a breakdown in talks between the UK and EU just days ahead of the latest scheduled Brexit summit that may now take the form of a no deal meeting given the ongoing Irish border impasse. Cable has managed to regain some composure and recoup losses under 1.3100, but Eur/Gbp is holding above 0.8800 where a hefty expiry lies (1 bn).

NZD/AUD - The next best majors and both extending gains above big figures at 0.6500 and 0.7100 respectively despite the aforementioned sell-off in equities overnight and Cnh weakness after a relatively stable Usd/Cny midpoint fix from the PBoC. Some support for the antipodean Dollars from firm commodity prices (oil and metals), while the Kiwi awaits NZ CPI data for Q3 later amidst expectations for a pick-up in headline inflation in q/q and y/y terms.

CHF/EUR/CAD - All narrowly mixed vs the Greenback that has eased off recent recovery highs (DXY back down towards 95.150 vs almost 95.400 at one stage), with the Franc not unduly ruffled by soft Swiss producer and import prices or latest comments from SNB chair Jordan stressing no need to adjust monetary policy and maintaining the option of direct intervention given the fragility of currency markets. Usd/Chf pivoting 0.9900 and Eur/Chf encircling 1.1450, as the single currency trades in a relatively narrow band either side of 1.1550 vs the Dollar. Note, the headline pair also has option expiries nearby with 1 bn running off from 1.1550-60, plus 1.2 bn on any break to 1.1500 or 1.1600-15.

EM - The Try remains bid just off 5.8160 peaks vs the Usd on follow-through buying/relief in wake of the release of US Pasto Brunson, while the Rub and Zar are also up vs the Buck (circa 65.6500 and 14.4500) on firm Brent and Gold.

COMMODITIES

Crude and Brent are up 0.6% and 0.9% respectively amidst supply concerns following possible U.S sanctions against Saudi Arabia over missing journalist Khashoggi, which Saudi say they will respond in kind to if implemented. Prices are currently just over USD 71.5/bbl and USD 81/bbl respectively. Additionally, IEA’s Birol stated that high oil prices are hurting consumers and that extra barrels will need to come to the market soon to avoid further tightening.

Gold is once again up with mass uncertainty in the market from unproductive Brexit talks, US-China trade war and Italian’s budget deadline day causing investors to move into the safe haven. Global trade tensions have also caused selling pressure in London metals causing prices to slip. Shanghai rebar steel futures climbed to their highest levels in over 3 weeks, boosted by expectations that China’s sustained anti-pollution campaign could further disrupt production.

FIXED INCOME

Not much change in core debt as the 10 year UK benchmark continues to marginally outpace its Eurozone equivalent having just eked out a fresh Liffe session high at 120.76 (+30 ticks), but Italian bonds have back-tracked from new intraday peaks of 120.49 to sub-120.00 again ahead of the budget presentation and a further Government meeting to finalise details and iron out any residual discrepancies. Meanwhile, Bunds have also lost some momentum after hitting some technical resistance at the early Eurex apex (158.84-87 flagged on some charts) and recently retreated to another low at 158.57 (+4 ticks), as US Treasuries remain depressed and the curve steeper in the run up to retail sales data.

EU MID-SESSION UPDATE: Cautious markets after an unproductive Brexit weekend

EQUITIES

Main European Indices are mixed amid current market uncertainty; the Dax is up (+0.3%) despite being weighed on by Lufthansa which is down by over 3% following agreements on new employment conditions, featuring moderate salary increases.

Sectors are mixed with IT lagging at -1% as a follow on from poor IT performance in Asia due to continued U.S-China tension; this is despite Friday’s Wall Street rebound for IT which saw it as the leading sector finishing up by 3%.

Convatec are down by over 25% following a cut in their revenue guidance. Chr Hansen are up by over 2% following a positive earnings update and reports that their chairman will not seek re-election, with Dominique Reiniche to be nominated as the next chairman.

FX

JPY - The clear G10 outperformer and beneficiary of a downturn in Asia-Pacific stocks as jitters over global trade, protectionism and sanctions undermined sentiment. Usd/Jpy has retreated from 112.25 highs and through 112.00 to a 111.70 low, breaching the 55 DMA at 111.83, while Eur/Jpy is back below 129.50 alongside broadly softer Jpy crosses. From a technical perspective, 111.50 will be eyed next on the downside as a psychological marker and 50% Fib, roughly aligning with daily support around 111.47 plus decent option expiry interest between 111.55-40 (1 bn).

GBP - At the opposite end of the spectrum, the Pound has been undermined by a breakdown in talks between the UK and EU just days ahead of the latest scheduled Brexit summit that may now take the form of a no deal meeting given the ongoing Irish border impasse. Cable has managed to regain some composure and recoup losses under 1.3100, but Eur/Gbp is holding above 0.8800 where a hefty expiry lies (1 bn).

NZD/AUD - The next best majors and both extending gains above big figures at 0.6500 and 0.7100 respectively despite the aforementioned sell-off in equities overnight and Cnh weakness after a relatively stable Usd/Cny midpoint fix from the PBoC. Some support for the antipodean Dollars from firm commodity prices (oil and metals), while the Kiwi awaits NZ CPI data for Q3 later amidst expectations for a pick-up in headline inflation in q/q and y/y terms.

CHF/EUR/CAD - All narrowly mixed vs the Greenback that has eased off recent recovery highs (DXY back down towards 95.150 vs almost 95.400 at one stage), with the Franc not unduly ruffled by soft Swiss producer and import prices or latest comments from SNB chair Jordan stressing no need to adjust monetary policy and maintaining the option of direct intervention given the fragility of currency markets. Usd/Chf pivoting 0.9900 and Eur/Chf encircling 1.1450, as the single currency trades in a relatively narrow band either side of 1.1550 vs the Dollar. Note, the headline pair also has option expiries nearby with 1 bn running off from 1.1550-60, plus 1.2 bn on any break to 1.1500 or 1.1600-15.

EM - The Try remains bid just off 5.8160 peaks vs the Usd on follow-through buying/relief in wake of the release of US Pasto Brunson, while the Rub and Zar are also up vs the Buck (circa 65.6500 and 14.4500) on firm Brent and Gold.

FIXED INCOME

Not much change in core debt as the 10 year UK benchmark continues to marginally outpace its Eurozone equivalent having just eked out a fresh Liffe session high at 120.76 (+30 ticks), but Italian bonds have back-tracked from new intraday peaks of 120.49 to sub-120.00 again ahead of the budget presentation and a further Government meeting to finalise details and iron out any residual discrepancies. Meanwhile, Bunds have also lost some momentum after hitting some technical resistance at the early Eurex apex (158.84-87 flagged on some charts) and recently retreated to another low at 158.57 (+4 ticks), as US Treasuries remain depressed and the curve steeper in the run up to retail sales data.

COMMODITIES

Crude and Brent are up 0.6% and 0.9% respectively amidst supply concerns following possible U.S sanctions against Saudi Arabia over missing journalist Khashoggi, which Saudi say they will respond in kind to if implemented. Prices are currently just over USD 71.5/bbl and USD 81/bbl respectively. Additionally, IEA’s Birol stated that high oil prices are hurting consumers and that extra barrels will need to come to the market soon to avoid further tightening.

Gold is once again up with mass uncertainty in the market from unproductive Brexit talks, US-China trade war and Italian’s budget deadline day causing investors to move into the safe haven. Global trade tensions have also caused selling pressure in London metals causing prices to slip. Shanghai rebar steel futures climbed to their highest levels in over 3 weeks, boosted by expectations that China’s sustained anti-pollution campaign could further disrupt production.

subject: UK debt and STIR futures building in Brexit breakdown buffer
content: As expected, catch-up gains in Gilts and Short Sterling contracts have been supplemented to an extent by latest Brexit developments, or rather the lack of any further progress in talks between the UK and EU ahead of this week’s summit. The 10 year benchmark is holding nearer the top of 120.59-70 parameters vs last Friday’s 120.46 Liffe close, while the 3 month strip is 1-3 ticks above parity and coming to terms with the fact that the Irish border issue threatens to derail a deal without more stop-gap arrangements, assuming other differences can be resolved and PM May manages to get parliament approval for whatever is on the table of course.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

15th October 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets resumed last week’s stock rout as the region failed to take impetus from Friday’s rebound on Wall St where tech outperformed and all majors finished a tumultuous session in the green, albeit with losses of around 4% on the week. ASX 200 (-0.8%) slumped from the open as financials and tech led the broad losses which dragged the index briefly below the 5800 level, while Nikkei 225 (-1.5%) suffered from continued flows into the JPY. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) and Hang Seng (-1.2%) conformed to the negative tone with sentiment not helped by President Trump’s reiteration that the US may have to impose another round of tariffs on China, with indecision seen in the mainland after the PBoC skipped open market operations and refrained from rolling over maturing MLF loans as its previously announced 100bps RRR cut took effect. Finally, 10yr JGBs were pressured at the open and tracked the recent weakness in T-notes, but then recovered as the widespread risk averse tone spurred safe-haven demand.

FTSE

Hochtief (HOT GY) / BHP Billiton (BLT LN) – Cimic (CIM AU), Hochtief’s Australian subsidiary said it’s Thiess division secured a USD 1.2bln contract from BHP Billiton (BLT LN) to provide mining services at the Mt Arthur coal operation. (Newswires)

UK Energy Names – Co.’s are calling for the regulator to intervene in the online switching market after it was discovered that 10% of the annual bill goes to comparison sites rather than to energy costs. (Times)

Barclays (BARC LN) – The co. is launching a retail account that is to offer US consumers a low-cost, digital-only bank. (FT)

Standard Chartered (STAN LN) – The co. is “actively working, on options for its holdings in PT Bank Permata, as according to the co.’s CEO. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

DAX

Deutsche Lufthansa (LHA GY) – The Lufthansa union, Vereinigung Cockpit has agreed on new employment conditions for its 650 pilots, including moderate salary increases for the next three years. (Newswires)

BMW (BMW GY) – According to Moodys, BMW’s plans to raise it’s stake in BMW brilliance is credit positive; adding that financing the EUR 3.6bln project will not affect BMW’s credit metrics. (Newswires)

RWE (RWE GY) – The German utility may have to cut jobs at it’s Hambach site after a court ruling that will delay plans to expand the mine by clearing an ancient forest; according to their chief executive. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

Prosiebensat.1 (PSM GY) – Their chief executive wants to double the market value of the German broadcaster in the next 3 to 5 years. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

SIEMENS HEALTHINEERS (SHL GY) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT HSBC

CAC

Accor (AC FP) – The co. is planning to reorganise by the end of this year, with 200 positions to be affected. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

ADP (ADP PA) – From the beginning of the year passenger traffic increased by 3.4%, September European traffic was up by 4.7% (excluding France which was down 0.1%). (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

SCANDINAVIA

content:

To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equity markets resumed last week’s stock rout as the region failed to take impetus from Friday’s rebound on Wall St
  • UK and EU negotiators called for a pause in discussions until Wednesday's summit outcome after UK PM May refused to endorse a draft Brexit deal negotiated by officials
  • In FX markets, the DXY was slightly firmer and continued its rebound from support at the 95.00 level while GBP/USD tested 1.3100 to the downside
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US retail sales and NY Fed manufacturing, Canadian Business Outlook, NZ CPI, Italian Budget Submission Deadline

ASIA

Asian equity markets resumed last week’s stock rout as the region failed to take impetus from Friday’s rebound on Wall St where tech outperformed and all majors finished a tumultuous session in the green, albeit with losses of around 4% on the week. ASX 200 (-0.8%) slumped from the open as financials and tech led the broad losses which dragged the index briefly below the 5800 level, while Nikkei 225 (-1.5%) suffered from continued flows into the JPY. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.8%) and Hang Seng (-1.2%) conformed to the negative tone with sentiment not helped by President Trump’s reiteration that the US may have to impose another round of tariffs on China, with indecision seen in the mainland after the PBoC skipped open market operations and refrained from rolling over maturing MLF loans as its previously announced 100bps RRR cut took effect. Finally, 10yr JGBs were pressured at the open and tracked the recent weakness in T-notes, but then recovered as the widespread risk averse tone spurred safe-haven demand.

PBoC skipped open market operations and refrained from rolling over maturing medium-term lending facility loans. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9154 (Prev. 6.9120)


UK

UK and EU negotiators called for a pause in discussions until Wednesday's summit outcome. Source reports suggested that all negotiations between UK and EU are on hold with the UK government reportedly telling ministers to begin 'no deal' implementation plans after last-ditch discussions broke up. (Times/Newswires) The breakdown in talks came after UK PM May refused to endorse a draft Brexit deal negotiated by UK and EU officials on Sunday night amid concerns the Cabinet would refuse to support the plan. UK PM May labelled the draft Brexit agreement a 'non-starter' in its current form and advisers are reportedly trying to craft new language for the Brexit withdrawal agreement amid signs the Cabinet will otherwise refuse to agree to PM May’s backstop proposals. Furthermore, it was also reported that EU leaders may not call for a special summit next month amid lack of progress. (Telegraph/FT)

EU leaders are set to hold an extraordinary “no deal” Brexit summit with a date pencilled in for the weekend of 17-18 November, to deal with the potential disaster of the UK crashing out of the bloc should PM May fail to deliver decisive progress on the Irish border issue this week. (The Guardian)

Former UK Foreign Minister Johnson said UK is entering moment of crisis in Brexit discussions and that matters cannot continue how they currently are, while he added the UK must resist being pushed around by EU. (Telegraph)

Former Brexit Secretary Davis has called for a cabinet uprising against UK PM May as MPs and ministers said they are ready to oust her if she does not change course on her Brexit plan. Writing to the Sunday Times, he called UK PM May’s plan “flawed” and “unacceptable”, while he accused the PM’s aides of “incipient panic” in the face of Brussel’s demands and trying to cut out the cabinet from key decisions. (The Times/BBC/Sky News)

Multiple Labour MPs told The Independent that they are prepared to support the Brexit agreement UK PM May hopes to bring back from Brussels, while the newspaper was also told that at least 15 Labour MPs could rebel against Labour leader Corbyn and back the government, which could be enough to tip the balance in the Commons in favour of a deal. (The Independent)

Scotland’s first minister is to press the case for continued membership of the single market and customs union by unveiling a “common-sense” alternative Brexit plan on Monday. (The Guardian)

UK PM May has been told that DUP Leader Foster is “ready” to trigger a no-deal Brexit as she believes this is the most likely outcome following a “hostile and difficult” meeting with EU’s Chief Negotiator Barnier, a set of leaked government emails revealed. (The Guardian)

The EY Item Club predicts GDP growth of 1.3% this year and 1.5% in 2019, down from 1.4% and 1.6% respectively in its previous outlook three months ago. (BBC)

UK Rightmove House Prices (Oct) M/M 1.0% (Prev. 0.7%). (Newswires)
UK Rightmove House Prices (Oct) Y/Y 0.9% (Prev. 1.2%)
 

EU

ECB President Draghi said underlying inflation is hovering around 1% but is confident it will proceed towards target, while he added that the main risk is a sharp repricing of assets or sudden increase in interest rates. Elsewhere, Draghi said he does not see room for additional expenditures in Italy and stated that ECB will not intervene to help Italy. (Newswires)

Germany’s CSU lost its absolute majority in the Bavarian state election and suffered its weakest result since 1950, according to an exit poll. (Twitter)

Sweden Moderate Party leader Kristersson is said to end current attempt to form a government after failing to receive enough support for a coalition. (Newswires)
 

FX

In FX markets, the DXY was slightly firmer and continued its rebound from support at the 95.00 level as its major counterparts traded subdued with EUR/USD little changed below 1.1600, while GBP/USD underperformed and tested 1.3100 to the downside on a lack of progress in Brexit negotiations with UK and EU negotiators calling for a pause in discussions until Wednesday's summit outcome. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY crosses remained pressured from safe-haven flows which saw the pair attempt a breakdown of the 112.00 handle, while antipodeans were somewhat unchanged alongside a relatively stable CNH and PBoC reference rate.

SNB Chairman Jordan said the situation in the FX market is still fragile and reiterated the willingness to intervene in FX if necessary, while Jordan also commented that it is appropriate to leave monetary policy unchanged as he sees no signs of "overheating". (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed with early upside in crude prices on US-Saudi friction after President Trump suggested the US will look into potential punishments if Saudi Arabia is found to have killed journalist Khashoggi, while Saudi rejected the threat of sanctions and warned it will respond to any measures against them. Conversely, gold prices were supported by safe-haven demand and copper traded sideways with price action contained within Friday’s tight range.

Baker Hughes Rig Count (12/Oct): Oil rigs +8 at 927 and gas rigs +4 at 193. (Newswires)

US President Trump said he will continue with the Saudi arms deal and look for other ways to “severely” punish the kingdom if they are found to have killed journalist Khashoggi, meanwhile Trump added that he has not yet seen the video and audio proof that Turkey claimed to have in regard to the journalist. Saudi Arabia later said it rejects any "threats" of sanctions or political pressure from the US over the disappearance of a journalist, while also warning it would respond to any steps taken against it. (Fox/SPA)

IEA's Birol said high oil prices are hurting consumers and that extra barrels will need to come to the market soon to avoid further tightening. (Twitter)

A fire on Nigerian state-owned pipeline on Osisioma Axis enar Aba has killed 16 and halted pumping. (Newswires)
 

US

Treasuries were negative on Friday amid a more constructive risk environment, where equities stabilised after the recent rout. The net result was that the T-Note traded within Thursday’s range. There were upticks after a soft Uni of Michigan sentiment survey, and the complex firmed towards the close after equities suffered a little wobble. Some desks were noting that dealers sold into the upswing. Major spreads were uneventful. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 1+ ticks lower at 118-11.

US President Trump reiterated the US might have to impose another round of tariffs on China. In other news, President Trump was reportedly unsure whether Defense Secretary Mattis will step down and suggested that Mattis was a sort of a Democrat. (Newswires)

White House Economic Adviser Kudlow said on Friday that we are in a hot market boom and that the stock market will get back on track, while he also commented that China's responses to the US are unsatisfactory and that US President Trump and Chinese President Xi will probably meet later this year. (Newswires)

US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin said that no decision has been made yet regarding a meeting between US President Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping at the G20 in Argentina, while Mnuchin also suggested the US would like to include currency stipulations in future trade agreements with everyone. (Newswires)

Finally, 10yr JGBs were pressured at the open and tracked the recent weakness in T-notes, but then recovered as the widespread risk averse tone spurred safe-haven demand.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia resumes stock rout
content:
Asia equity markets resumed last week’s stock rout as the region failed to take impetus from Friday’s rebound on Wall St where tech outperformed and all majors finished a tumultuous session in the green, albeit with losses of around 4% on the week. ASX 200 (-1.1%) slumped from the open with financials and tech leading the broad losses which dragged the index briefly below the 5800 level, while Nikkei 225 (-1.4%) suffers from continued flows into the JPY. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-0.1%) and Hang Seng (-1.2%) conform to the negative tone with sentiment not helped by President Trump’s reiteration that the US may have to impose another round of tariffs on China, although the mainland index is choppy after the PBoC skipped open market operations and refrained from rolling over maturing MLF loans as its previously announced 100bps RRR cut took effect.

In FX markets, the DXY is slightly firmer and continues its rebound from support at the 95.00 level as its major counterparts trade subdued with EUR/USD little changed below 1.1600, while GBP/USD underperforms and briefly tested 1.3100 to the downside on a lack of a breakthrough in Brexit negotiations with UK and EU negotiators calling for a pause in discussions until Wednesday's summit outcome. Elsewhere, USD/JPY and JPY crosses remain pressured from safe-haven flows which saw the pair test 112.00 to the downside, while antipodeans are somewhat unchanged alongside a relatively stable CNH and PBoC reference rate.

Finally, 10yr JGBs gapped lower at the open to track the weakness in T-notes, but then recovered as the widespread risk averse tone spurred safe-haven demand.
